{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3200703,"name":"fovea1959","username":"fovea1959","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fovea1959/{size}/5301_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T21:47:55.202Z","cooked":"

We’re working on an automated battery tester for offseason. One thing I’d like to explore is automatically identifying the battery (both in the test stand, and in the robot).

I’m thinking that RFID is the way to go: does anyone have any advice on some cheap reader/card combinations?

Alternatives?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T21:47:55.202Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":71,"reads":713,"readers_count":712,"score":542.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"fovea1959","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Herder of 3620 Programmers / LRI / CSA"},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/1","custom_user_title":"Herder of 3620 Programmers / LRI / CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3200711,"name":"Kiera Reed","username":"kierajreed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kierajreed/{size}/170522_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T22:01:10.250Z","cooked":"

Team 6328 has an awesome QR-code-based system that was discussed in their 2022 thread:

FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2022 Build Thread Open Alliance
Software Update #7: The Log Behind the Curtain As we complete the final preparations before shipping our robot to Houston, I’d like to take a moment to reflect on some software topics from our last event at Greater Boston. Odometry Tuning With a new motorized hood to control, we had to rely on accurate vision and odometry data more than ever before. As I’ve discussed previously, we use an averaging system for odometry where the weight of the vision data vs. existing drive data is tunable (and a…

You could also use barcodes

This is what we (6328) ended up doing for the 2023 season due to some new space constraints compared to the solution that @kierajreed linked above.

FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2023 Build Thread Open Alliance
Software Update #5: The Kitchen Sink We haven’t done a dedicated software post for (checks notes) two months… There’s a lot to talk about, so here’s a collection of mostly-unrelated-but-hopefully-interesting software projects we’ve been working on. As always, we’re happy to answer any questions. Autos & “The Questionnaire” We were honored to receive the autonomous award at the WPI District Event. So let’s talk more about autos… We decided early on that there were some key improvements we need…

QR or Bar codes are fantastic systems that tend to be easy to implement

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T22:07:30.930Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":555,"readers_count":554,"score":111.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/6","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200720,"name":"Technologyman00","username":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T22:09:35.493Z","cooked":"

Another solution could be adding an additional connector alongside to the main battery connector that provides a unique resistance for each battery.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T22:09:35.493Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":540,"readers_count":539,"score":133.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Technologyman00","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25951,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7900, 1792, 1714"},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/7","custom_user_title":"7900, 1792, 1714","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200738,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T22:38:25.823Z","cooked":"
fovea1959:

I’m thinking that RFID is the way to go

This was our first thought too, but it is in violation of R707 (“No other wireless allowed”). Short-range though it is, RFID is still, inarguably, wireless communication.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T22:38:25.823Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":512,"readers_count":511,"score":157.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Brett B Bonner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48574,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls"},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/8","custom_user_title":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200753,"name":"Dan","username":"theworkshope","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T22:57:21.250Z","cooked":"

A passive NFC tag should not violate that as it doesn’t “wirelessly communicate” unless it’s in a pretty specific electromagnetic field (that’s very limited in power and range). Using the colloquial names here, an RFID tag similar to a key fob should be allowable.

Rules of course are rules, on the practical side the frequencies used by these devices are very very far away from interfering with FMS/ radios.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T22:59:00.985Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":471,"readers_count":470,"score":104.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48574,"username":"bbonner","name":"Brett B Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53412,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200757,"name":"Ben","username":"Bzc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bzc/{size}/213635_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T23:03:26.342Z","cooked":"

I think it’s because their system has a scanner installed on the robot to check the battery on startup. If you wanted to use this system then you would have wireless communication on your robot, so it would violate the rule.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T23:03:26.342Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":441,"readers_count":440,"score":98.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Ben","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53412,"username":"theworkshope","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54644,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 8727"},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/10","custom_user_title":"FRC 8727","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200758,"name":"Dan","username":"theworkshope","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-27T23:04:27.676Z","cooked":"

Got it, I was thinking separate from the robot only. That’s interesting…

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-27T23:04:27.676Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":422,"readers_count":421,"score":84.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54644,"username":"Bzc","name":"Ben","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bzc/{size}/213635_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53412,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200860,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-28T01:45:15.307Z","cooked":"
Bzc:

I think it’s because their system has a scanner installed on the robot to check the battery on startup.

That is correct, our goal was to track battery usage on-robot automatically, which requires that the system be on-board. While I agree that it’s unlikely RFID would interfere with anything, the rule sadly doesn’t have any exception for it.

QR/bar codes worked well, though do require a bit of thought to arrange in a way where the tags are visible to the scanner.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-28T01:45:15.307Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":405,"readers_count":404,"score":121.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"Brett B Bonner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48574,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls"},"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/12","custom_user_title":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200864,"name":"","username":"Autumn-Ou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/autumn-ou/{size}/192598_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-28T01:51:58.700Z","cooked":"

Just a question, why QR over bar codes, I know they support more data and are easy to set up with any random camera and a cheap potatoe but wouldn’t a bar code scanner be more space efficient and be able to be put close r?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-04-28T01:51:58.700Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":385,"readers_count":384,"score":97.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":436129,"topic_slug":"identifying-batteries-rfid","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48574,"username":"bbonner","name":"Brett B Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Making funky products"},"user_suspended":true,"post_url":"/t/identifying-batteries-rfid/436129/13","custom_user_title":"Making funky products","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3200875,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-28T02:06:06.097Z","cooked":"
Autumn-Ou:

why QR over bar codes

The scanner we have does both and plugs directly into the Rio. Last year QR at a fairly large scale worked well because of where the battery was & available space to mount the scanner above it. This year with a 25x25 frame we were VERY tight on space and could only just squeeze in the bar codes in a place where we could point the scanner. In practice we had more bar-code read failures this year than we had QR scan failures last year even after we embiggened the bar codes as much as we could. That may be a function of still-not-optimal positioning or it may be that QR codes are just more error tolerant. Regardless, both clearly are viable solutions since all we need is a unique identifier per battery.

fovea1959:

Did you interface using USB or serial?

There’s a micro-USB port on the bottom side of the board. We cabled it directly into a Rio USB-A port. The scanner can be configured to present as a serial-over-USB device so it was pretty trivial to interface to in software. Our interface code is here.

The scanner is a little quirky to set up - it’s configured by scanning sequences of QR codes from its manual.

Fun fact: the board is just small enough to slip into a length of 1/16"-wall 1x1 tubing, which makes for an awfully handy way to mount and protect it. Just requires carefully drilling some holes in the tube for the pre-mounted threaded studs to slip through. We stood it off with an extra nut on each stud on the inside, so as to have the bottom-mount USB clear the tube.

We submitted a Q and A this season about this fact. FIRST FRC Q&A System

I have purchased but not yet tested this: Adafruit PN532 NFC/RFID Controller Shield for Arduino + Extras : ID 789 : $39.95 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits with a few different Tags.

We too would like a passive way to id the battery that does not require optics or any user input. I plan to follow up with the FIRST inspectors team to see if there is any way to allow “Near Field Communications” In my opinion and this could be wrong the R707 seems to be there to eliminate other remote controlled sources to our robots. If more people begin to request this then it could gain attention.
